text: Family Member: Oh, I got you. Doctor: Radium, there’s liquid radiation, there’s Xofigo, which is the trade name, and, you know, we don’t give it but the radiation oncology doctors give it because it is a form of radiation. So, they’ll go over everything but what I would do is we would start the prior authorization process with our insurance but you then would talk to the radiation oncology doctor for a formal consultation and then they go over the pros and cons of what’s gonna happen and so on and so on. Patient: You know about it I’m sure about this. You know about the radiation that I had Doctor: Uh huh. Yep Patient: and is it similar to that or is the… Doctor: Different. Patient: Side effects? Doctor: You could have had the radiation. This is intravenous infusion. You know what this is, is the stuff that Marie Curie discovered all those years ago in the late eighteen hundreds. That’s what she discovered to try to treat cancer and now we actually use to treat cancer. Patient: Oh, wow! Doctor: Yeah. It’s just in smaller doses. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, I think the fact you’ve had radiation before is not, you know, an issue.

text: Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: You want us to print it? Patient: Seven to twenty nine. Doctor: Yeah, it is, it is a mess. Patient: I haven't read it before. Doctor: I mean, most of it is, um, I say usual, you might get tired, because tired is always tops of everything. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And so that would be something that you know, based on sort of, if we really think T12 is real or T3 is real, that could be something that we would send you off to the radiation doctors to have them talk about that trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then we get the PET scan and it actually says, you know, you've got 123 plus 456, you know, that we think most of this is real, we can step back and watch a little bit longer until either declares itself a little bit more. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or just say hey, it's there. And then we have a couple studies where the current standard for the guy who shows up with multiple spots is to go on hormones for life. Patient: Right. Doctor: And add either chemo or add a hormone drug to it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that would be what we would talk about. We do have trials where we're trying to even build on that. Okay, so hormones plus chemo plus immune therapy or hormones plus hormone therapy plus immune system drugs. Patient: Right. Doctor: So how, you know, one is sort of yet such small disease that we're going to try to manage it without using a traditional method, versus we think you've got so much disease that we're going to throw the kitchen sink at you, right? text: Family Member: It’s K___ lab. L___ will, uh, communicate with A___ from K___, and she’ll, uh, we’ll send her the script. Doctor: Please let L___ know about this. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So we’ll get you a prescription through K___ to do a blood test next Tuesday, let’s say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or whatever day works for you. And, and that’s one of the precautions to see if, if the stopping of the drug for a week is causing the hemoglobin to increase on its own. And if it’s not, and we need some help with that, that’s when a blood transfusion would come into play. Patient: Okay. Now, so, along with what we’ve talked about, if we decide that, uh, uh, the, uh, the clinical trial is not working- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Then, what I’m going to do is go back to K___? And so J___ H___ will not be involved anymore after that? Doctor: So let’s talk about that for a second. So there are two main options. One is that if you wanted to pursue a standard therapy, such as enzalutamide, also called Xtandi, or chemotherapy, that would be through K___, because as a standard therapy, you will not have privileges, unless you paid out of pocket, to come here for that therapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: On the other hand, the second possibility is to participate in a different clinical trial. So I’ll give you one example. So we have a trial right now testing immunotherapy against prostate cancer. That is a drug that stimulates your own immune system to hopefully fight and kill the cancer. Okay? That’s just one example. We might have at least one more trial that you’re also eligible for. But both of these trials would not really rely on that mutation, specifically, but they are just trials that you would still qualify for, uh, independent of the mutation.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can tell you that the most important thing you can do is not gain weight. You do not need a special diet; you do not need special things. What is important is you don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you stay physically active. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all that’s important because I mean what is bad is if you get fat, fat is a pro-inflammatory environment and people who do get fat die quicker from cancer. All cancers. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, so, all these diets and things like that, all these special things people offer often at high prices, you know it’s great if you need that discipline, but the reality is don’t gain weight. Stay in shape; you’ll do better. Patient: So like worrying about my sugar intake and - Doctor: Don’t – in or out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don’t gain weight. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Everything. Um, well, I’m feeling better now but I think I’m feeling better because my stomach- Doctor: Yeah. Well you’re away now more time away from radiation. Patient: Exactly. Doctor: So you know radiation is tough. It helps the pain but it’s always something for something, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: not something for nothing, so there’s some side effects there. And you got a lot of radiation. Patient: So the question there being then probably safe to go back on the supplements? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
